sub_title: Full Professor Bone Biochemistry, Radboud University Medical Center, Nijmegen
summary:
My research focusses on the mechanisms of mineralization in bone formation and in pathological calcification, where I use creative imaging approaches to study the structural and (bio)chemical aspects of these processes with the highest spatial and temporal resolution. 

Unraveling the molecular mechanisms of biological mineralization processes is of the greatest importance for the development of new therapeutic strategies that will help to shift treatments from surgical intervention to prevention, e.g. in the treatment of Calcifying Aortic Valve Disease. 

To study the biological processes as close as possible to the native conditions we emulate matrix formation and mineralization using human in vitro systems, including organoids and bone-on-a-chip devices. We monitor these processes with a variety of advanced microscopic and spectroscopic methods to cover all relevant length and time scales (www.mineralizedtissues.com). 

These advanced imaging strategies are developed within the Radboud Electron Microscopy Center, where we closely collaborate with many companies (Zeiss, CryoCapCell, Thermo Fischer/FEI, DENSsolutions, VitroTEM) to constantly improve our imaging capabilities and to push the boundaries of the science and eventually healthcare.
